values:
I am doing two days of work, packing and stressing out right this minute. Mostly so that I can go to Colorado by way of Tulsa tomorrow. I'll be at Ty's Hamburgers (along with 
vadius
) Saturday at noon.

That is all.

I have no words. Watch the video.
<lj-embed id="2" />

I'm sure there is not actually a human being left on the planet that does not know that I adore the various works of Neal Stephenson. I have obsessed over "The Diamond Age," "Zodiac," "Snow Crash," and "Cryptonomicon," reading each many many many times. I keep threatening to reread "The Baroque Cycle," but that is a commitment. I not only own "The Big U" but I've read it. I even have one or two positive things to say about it, though, dear Lord in Heaven above, it was clearly a first novel. I am incredibly excited about "Anathem." I even grabbed copies the two books Stephenson wrote under an assumed name with Stephen Bury ("Interface" and "The Cobweb" for anyone keeping up).

I just finished reading "Interface" this week and I have come to the conclusion that Neal Stephenson is stalking me. The consistent little references to Ames, Iowa throughout basically every book Stephenson's written started my suspicions back in the day when I first read "The Diamond Age" (the first of Stephenson's books I stumbled across).

//Lord Alexander Chung-Sik Finkle-McGraw was from Ames and has a bit of a flashback about it. There are plenty of other little references throughout his work.

But Ames, IA is easily explainable. My mom graduated a year behind Stephenson from Ames High. Pure happenstance. Then there's random little comments about Ft. Meade and nearby Maryland. You know, the area I'm currently living in. And then, there's "Interface": nice solid scenes of not only Denver, Colorado but the crazy empty little suburbs spreading around the city. Seriously. Stephenson's everywhere that I am!

//Okay, well to the extent that he's been there long before I actually get there. But I'm still arguing the point.

That's okay, though. As long as he keeps writing tasty treats for me to read, Mr. Stephenson can stalk me anywhere.

After a number of attempts to give into the temptation, 
vadius
 and I managed to finally acquire a Wii. Ooooh and the newest Zelda game, which is quite pretty.

I managed to knock a guy in Wii Boxing. I'm very proud of myself and intend to knock out many more dudes. Ooooh and Tetris!

In general, the whole situation is quite pleasing. It was pure serendipity that we got one, as well. The Target on Powers (in Colorado Springs) was supposed to get a shipment of Wiis yesterday morning, and my mother was going to go pick one up and FedEx it to use. (This is after many driving-arounds and phone calls.) We went over to the Target here in Laurel to purchase something else, before the Target in the Springs actually opened. Target had a number closely resembling 12, completely unexpectedly.

I have been allowed to name the Wii Herbert. He looks like a Herbert, just so you know. An absolutely delightful little Herbert.

Guess how many trick-or-treaters we had last night! No, really, guess!









Absolutely none. 

I am so disappointed.

I intended to regale you all with photographic evidence of my resemblance to Kaylee. Unfortunately, all the pretty iron ons I put on to the coveralls I obtained through nefarious means fell back off immediately.

So, I distract you with kittens!


Here is Charlie, hiding behind the pumpkin. Alas, Mr. Pumpkin was unable to protect her, and in fact attempted to eat her later in the evening. (More on that later).
Below is dear brother D.K. who was trapped by the vicious webs I put up for my own entertainment.














Onwards to that cat-eating pumpkin I mentioned.
vadius
 and I carved pumpkins, and mine got all toothy and hungry. In this photo, it is seen devouring a hapless teddy bear who was innocently wandering by. How sad.

DO YOU KNOW WHAT TODAY IS? IF NOT, JUST READING THIS SHOULD PROVIDE A CLUE!

INTERNATIONAL CAPS LOCK DAY!

I WOULD LIKE TO NOTE THAT THERE SEEMS TO BE A MINOR DISPUTE OUT THERE IN THE INTERNET, OVER WHETHER THE HOLIDAY ACTUALLY FALLS TODAY OR ON THE 24TH.





Dear lord, enough of that. Just looking at all those capitalized letters gives me a headache from all the noise.

I got my election judgin' paperwork in the mail yesterday. Yeah. That's right. For both the primary and presidential elections in Howard County, Maryland, I'm an election judge. Muhahaha. I control the vote!

Okay, not really. I'll be a check-in judge. People will show up to vote, show me some ID and I'll give them a ballot. Still, this whole democracy in action thing is kinda cool.

And profitable. I'll make $165.00 for each election, plus $30 for attending a training session next month. I'm content with the arrangement.

Normally, I don't add an author to my 'to read' list just on the basis that he or she won some sort of prize. For Doris Lessig, I'm making an exception solely on her immediate response to finding out that she had won the Nobel Prize for Literature:

(From Jezebel, here)
Today, the press greeted Golden Notebook author Doris Lessing as she arrived at her home in a taxi. In the clip above, they tell her she was awarded the Nobel Prize for literature, and her response is, "Oh Christ. I couldn't care less." She's the saltiest! What's not seen in the clip is that reporters then tried to elicit a more printable quote from Lessing, and when one of them reminded her about the $1.5 million cash prize she said, "I'm already thinking about all the people who are going to send me begging letters -- I can see them lining up now."

The woman is officially brilliantly eccentric, and I can only aspire to her level.

By way of introduction: I like Iron Chef. I like Iron Chef America. I like the idea of rushed culinary battles based on secret ingredients. It amuses me to no end. So now, Food Network has offered up The Next Iron Chef, an elimination-style reality show. Luckily, they are eliminating real, brilliant chefs.

I got excited about this. It may be a sign that I'm a bit addicted to cooking shows (and Alton Brown in particular), but I'm actually willing to watch a reality show. I was cheering for Traci Des Jardines, one of two women in the starting 8. She's been on Iron Chef America before and is pretty kickass.

The first episode of The Next Iron Chef was last night. There was a race involving deboning chicken. Every reality show should have chicken-deboning races. Then there was a dessert making section, where the chefs each had a different savory ingredient (squid, chorizo, bacon, etc.) My girl, Traci, got salmon eggs. John Besh won the round with catfish truffles.

Now, here is the sad part. At the end of the first episode, Traci was eliminated. I am so disappointed. I am at a loss for who to root for now.

It really is. She sent us youtube videos of musical numbers from Bollywood flicks and began our horrible downfall.

(Spoilers ahead)

So, blame her for my subjecting you to a brief review of "Kuch Kuch Hota Hai", here on imdb. 177 minutes of dancing, costume changes and very pretty people. Based on the subtitles, I believe that the title translates literally as "Something Happens." Additionally, I believe that the something in question seems to be someone falling in love (which happens several times). Then again, I could be making it all up

One of the underlying themes here seems to be whether it is alright for a man to remarry if he is widowed. Rahul, the male lead, looses his wife in child birth and mopes around for about 8 years, doting on his daughter, named Anjali after his best friend. When little Anjali turns 8, she learns of her namesake (in an hour long flashback!) and deviously plots to bring them back together and score herself a new mother. She enlists her paternal grandmother and maternal grandfather in her complicated plot and discovers that the older Anjali is due to be married.

Little Anjali ain't havin' none of that! More devious schemes ensue, culminating in her father and his friend running into each other at summer camp. Somehow, Anjali's betrothed is convinced to give her up and Rahul gets the girl (again).

All this plot is surrounded by approximately 30 million songs, each with fifteen or so costume changes.

I believe I have discovered the secret to making adequate cheesecake (the tasty edible thing with origins in cream cheese, not the thing with pictures of pretty scantily clad ladies), and that thing is the freezer.

Aren't you especially glad I noted that I wasn't making posters, so you didn't think I was keeping girls in my freezer?

The real issue is that I made a cheesecake from scratch and it came out somewhat gloopy. But I popped it in the freezer and it is tres excellent when dished up and only barely thawed.

My little sister's 16th birthday is tomorrow. She wants a party with her 40 closest friends. 

I, on the other hand, can't even name 40 people I like.

So, I was in Ireland during the Six Nations rugby games. It turns out this is a bad thing, because I now think rugby is quite fabulous. After extensive bemoaning of the fact that American sports networks don't cover rugby, imagine my delight when I found out that whatever channel is number 75 on our set is showing the World Cup matches. *squee*

I figured this out last night, part way into the England / South Africa match. As I understand it, England won the Cup last year. Last night, they lost to South Africa 0 to 36. That's right -- England, which basically invented the whole damn sport, got 'smushed like bug'. Unfortunately, it appears that my mystery channel isn't airing all the games though, so here's to hunting YouTube for random clips.

A belated happy birthday to 
neeman
, in keeping with today's Irish theme. I hope it was a good one.

I just wrote feminist science fiction. Now I'm considering writing bodice rippers. Either way, I'm going to use a pen name and never admit to it again.

Ooooh, I'm going to the special literary hell.

Some of you may remember Hector, the aloe vera plant I obtained through entirely non-dubious means in Oliphant Hall. He's had a rough couple of months...

Let's step back in time for a moment. In March of 2004, I received Franz a.k.a. Fronds. Even my aunt, who sent him to me, has no idea of Franz's genetic heritage -- she asked the man at the florist's to send me something 'hardy'. And hardy Franz was. He survived 5 moves, months without water, years without sunlight and other trauma no good plant should be forced to face (leaf?). 

Poor Franz was truly killed through kindness. I spent the summer of 2005 at home, and my mother simply added Franz to her plant routine. He was watered regularly and moved outside into the sun daily. Poor bastard got used to it. When he returned to my tender care, he was bundled into the car for ten hours and then stuck in my living room. Sometimes, he'd get watered. 

Suffice it to say, Franz didn't do so well anymore. I noted his passing and mourned a bit. Eventually Hector came into my life. Hector's distinct phenotype argued in favor of his ability to survive my haphazard attentions, and he has generally lived up to it, thanks to vadius' regular reminders. D.K. and Charlie, however, have grown inordinately fond of him. Unfortunate little green thing. They believe him to be *shudder* tasty. He lived on the counter until 'The Cat on Plant Incident of June 2007', where upon he took refuge on top of the refrigerator. Last week, Charlie realized just how easy it was to hop on top of the fridge. This recent assassination attempt forced us to consider further relocation, and Franz took up a new residence on the balcony. My very loose watering schedule called for me to check in on him yesterday, and, well, he has not adjusted to the heat and humidity. My version of the Witness Protection program experienced its second failure. 

I had to take extreme measures. Where could I place Hector that was reasonably safe? It took me a moment to come up with at least a stopgap solution.

That, in short, is why Hector now abides in the shower.

Kaplan lost a multi-million dollar contract with Baltimore schools. I'm not snickering or anything. I just thought is was worth mentioning.

The contract was for helping overhaul the school district's curriculum, and many Baltimore-ians had (legitimate) concerns that a) it was too expensive and b) it was unnecessary.

I should put in a bid...

So, um, yeah, I can't really think of anything in particular to say here. Is that a symptom of the fact that I spend most days typing blogs and articles and Twitters, spreading the seed of my opinion near and far? I have an awful lot of opinion, but there may be a finite limit.

Yeah. Right. Thursday not having an opinion. Thursday being quiet. *snicker*

In other news, the kitties are extra special. Today, they attempted to eat vadius's flipflops. There was food in their dish and all. They're just *special*.

The freelancing is going. I'm not making every dollar in the universe, but I am making dollars. The blog continues to happen, of which I am exceptionally proud. I also now know too much about social networking, and I think I should start learning about grant writing. It looks very interesting.

Also, I continue to have toes.
"I would be most content if my children grew up to be the kind of people who think decorating consists mostly of building enough bookshelves." -- Anna Quindlen

So, I'm trying this old fashioned blogging doohickey. thursdaybram.com. It's mostly about freelance writing, so I'm sure absolutely no one has any interest in that.

In other news... that new job? Not so much. I have this whole ethics thing, and they didn't seem to, so much.

Everything else is shiny, though.

Well, I officially have a new job. 

It's not an exciting job. I make phone calls all day. 

But it pays.

At least I'm not trying to sell anything.

I am teh back!

In numeric summation: 

12 days in Israel (with one day trip to Jordan)
989 photos taken (excluding the really bad blurry ones I deleted)
0 Arabic countries I ever intend to visit again
1 wedding and 1 birth missed (many apologies and congratulations, by the way)
2 shekels per minute for internet access
4 shekels to the U.S. dollar
2 seas swam in (Dead & Red)
13 relatives miraculously survived the entire experience intact
2 friends from back home surprisingly seen

Still trying and failing to catch up.

I'm not dead yet. I'm just very busy -- and my busy-ness is of my own devising. I've been posting semi-regularly to Twitter, because I'm really only bright enough to handle things in small chunks.

I have yet to persuade some poor sap into hiring me (although I've signed back up to teach Kaplan). I am, however, making a minute amount of dough by freelance writing. I've also been making muffins. Lots of muffins. I'm planning to switch to cupcakes shortly.

So, yes, if you need freelance writing or PR-ing done, let me know. (If you have a sick, morbid fascination with such things, or just want to point and laugh, I'm generally posting links to my horrible writings via Twitter). And if anything entertaining happens, let me know.

We're in Maryland! 

I'm never driving that far again. Hell, I may never drive again period. Because I can clearly do that.

And I'm back in the game!

Alright, schedule as follows: the next week or so will be in Colorado Springs with potentially one day in Denver/Boulder. Then a week in Tulsa. Then Baltimore. 

If you want to do something, let me know. :)
I just finished the last paper of my undergraduate life. I feel a distinct need to fall over.

I'm going to be a sorta-aunt again! (My mother's goddaughter is having the baby.) The baby's due in August.

And this time, I'm getting a niece! After a bazillion boys, I'm getting a niece. I'm totally going to spoil her and teach her to fight dirty.

I had my first interaction with a saint yesterday. It went surprisingly well. Of course, he's been dead for something like 400 years. 

They keep his head in a box. A see-through box.

There must be some kind of way out of here
Said the joker to the thief
Theres too much confusion
I cant get no relief
Businessman they drink my wine
Plow men dig my earth
None will level on the line
Nobody of it is worth
Hey hey

No reason to get excited
The thief he kindly spoke
There are many here among us
Who feel that life is but a joke but uh
But you and I weve been through that
And this is not our fate
So let us not talk falsely now
The hours getting late
Hey

Hey

All along the watchtower
Princes kept the view
While all the women came and went
Bare-foot servants to, but huh
Outside in the cold distance
A wild cat did growl
Two riders were approachin
And the wind began to howl
Hey
Oh
All along the watchtower
Hear you sing around the watch
Gotta beware gotta beware I will
Yeah
Ooh baby
All along the watchtower

So, I was informed that I dress in "my boyfriend's closet chic." 

It probably wouldn't be so bad if *every* time I had gone to do laundry in the past three weeks, somebody else's crap wasn't in there. I actually managed to find it empty yesterday morning, and then found out we didn't actually have water. As in absolutely nothing comes out of the tap. Jesus Christ on a pogo stick.

In other news, I did have enough to drink on St. Patty's Day that I provided conclusive proof that I know all the words to Dolly Parton's "9 to 5." My dork fu is strong.

I have firmly cemented my position as alpha nerd here:

I obtained a pie and went around the IES centre demanding everyone join me in celebrating Pi Day. The Irish looked at me funny because, for them, it's 14/03/07. The Americans looked at me funny because I'm a huge freakin' nerd.

But the pie tasted very yummy and I am content'd. 

Off to celebrate the Ides of March.
Sometimes I get the feeling that I'm in the wrong time zone...
